It belongs to the Gesneriaceae family and is characterized by its striking, showy flowers that are typically pink or red in color. The plant is typically found growing in moist, shaded areas of tropical forests, often in the understory where it thrives in partial shade. Its leaves are usually elliptical and have a glossy surface, while its stems are slender and often covered in fine hairs. Cyrtandra cominsii is a rare and endangered species, facing threats from habitat loss and invasive species.
